title: CLAUDE.md
text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: MAIVE (Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator) R package implements instrumental variable approaches limit bias caused spurious precision meta-analysis. package addresses problem observational research precision can manipulated p-hacking, invalidating traditional inverse-variance weighting bias-correction methods. Project Page: http://meta-analysis.cz/maive/ GitHub: meta-analysis-es/maive

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Install from GitHub devtools::install_github("meta-analysis-es/maive")  # Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps()  # Load package in-place for development pkgload::load_all()

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Run all tests pkgload::load_all() testthat::test_dir("tests/testthat")  # Or from command line Rscript -e 'pkgload::load_all(); testthat::test_dir("tests/testthat")'  # Run single test file testthat::test_file("tests/testthat/test-maive_first_stage.R")

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Generate documentation from roxygen comments devtools::document()  # View help for main function ?maive

title: CLAUDE.md
text: tag push triggers CRAN submission workflow automatically.
code: # Ensure clean working directory, then bump version (auto-commits, tags, pushes) make version-patch   # 0.1.4 -> 0.1.5 (bug fixes) make version-minor   # 0.1.4 -> 0.2.0 (new features) make version-major   # 0.1.4 -> 1.0.0 (breaking changes)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: main exported functions maive() waive() (defined R/maivefunction.r), perform meta-analysis using instrumental variable estimation. functions share common pipeline via maive_run_pipeline(): Input Validation (maive_validate_inputs): Validates normalizes input parameters Data Preparation (maive_prepare_data): Prepares study-level data, handles clustering fixed effects dummy matrix centering Variance Instrumentation (maive_compute_variance_instrumentation): First-stage regression variances inverse sample sizes, supporting levels log transformations Weighting (maive_compute_weights): Computes weights based weighting scheme (none, inverse-variance, MAIVE-adjusted, WAIVE) Shared Pipeline (maive_run_pipeline): Common second-stage analysis used maive() waive() Model Fitting (maive_fit_models): Fits PET (Precision-Effect Test), PEESE (Precision-Effect Estimate Standard Error), combined models Method Selection (maive_select_petpeese, maive_fit_ek): Selects PET/PEESE fits Endogenous Kink (EK) models Confidence Intervals (maive_compute_egger_ar_ci): Computes Anderson-Rubin confidence intervals weak instruments (handled R/ar.r) Bootstrap (R/boot.r): Wild cluster bootstrap standard errors SE=3

title: CLAUDE.md
text: maive() function expects data frame : Column 1: bs - Primary estimates Column 2: sebs - Standard errors (must > 0) Column 3: Ns - Sample sizes (must > 0) Column 4 (optional): study_id - Study identification clustering/fixed effects

title: CLAUDE.md
text: method: 1=PET, 2=PEESE, 3=PET-PEESE (default), 4=EK weight: 0=none (default), 1=inverse-variance, 2=MAIVE-adjusted instrument: 0=, 1=yes (default) - whether instrument standard errors studylevel: 0=none, 1=fixed effects, 2=cluster (default), 3=SE: 0=CR0 (Huber-White), 1=CR1, 2=CR2, 3=wild bootstrap (default) AR: 0=, 1=yes (default) - compute Anderson-Rubin CI (unweighted IV) first_stage: 0=levels (default), 1=log - first-stage functional form Note: WAIVE available standalone waive() function robust downweighting spurious precision outliers.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: studylevel parameter encodes two dimensions via modular arithmetic: cluster = studylevel %/% 2 (integer division) dummy = studylevel %% 2 (modulo) Study fixed effects demeaned intercept measures grand mean. implemented via maive_center_dummy_matrix() centers dummy variables drops one column.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: AR CI computation (R/ar.r) uses adaptive grid search performance optimizations: Grid resolution adapts sample size parameter uncertainty Pre-computes projection matrices efficiency Disables AR datasets >5000 observations avoid memory issues Uses tighter bounds (2.5 standard errors) better performance available unweighted IV estimators

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Two functional forms instrumenting variances (sebs¬≤): Levels (first_stage=0): Linear regression sebs¬≤ constant 1/Ns Log (first_stage=1): Log-linear regression smearing retransformation handle heteroskedasticity log specification uses Duan‚Äôs smearing estimator retransform predictions back levels.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Returns named list : Estimate, SE: Main MAIVE point estimate standard error StdEstimate, StdSE: Standard (non-IV) estimate comparison Hausman: Hausman-type test statistic comparing IV vs OLS intercepts F-test: First-stage F-test (instrumenting) AR_CI: Anderson-Rubin confidence interval (AR=1 conditions met) SE_instrumented: Instrumented standard errors vector pbias_pval: p-value publication bias test based instrumented FAT

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Tests organized tests/testthat/ fixtures tests/testthat/fixtures/. Test files follow naming convention test-{component}.R. Key test patterns: Tests access internal functions using MAIVE:::function_name syntax Tests manually reconstruct computation pipelines verify individual components Fixtures contain datasets regression testing (e.g., egger_ar_no_acceptance.csv)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Study fixed effects always demeaned, maive_center_dummy_matrix() drops one column centering Hausman test uses difference--estimators variance (conservative approach) AR CI automatically disabled weighted methods non-IV estimation Wild bootstrap (SE=3) uses Rademacher multipliers cluster level robust standard errors use clubSandwich package CR0/CR1/CR2 estimators Infinite bounds AR computation handled optimization compute_AR_CI_optimized()

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Core dependencies: stats, utils: Base R functionality clubSandwich: Cluster-robust variance estimation metafor: Meta-analysis framework Development dependencies: testthat: Testing framework devtools: Package development tools pkgload: Load package development

title: CRAN Submission Guide

text: simplest way release. Requires clean working directory. single command: Validates clean working directory Bumps version DESCRIPTION Commits message chore: bump version X.Y.Z Creates git tag vX.Y.Z Pushes commit tag GitHub Triggers CRAN submission workflow Monitor progress : https://github.com/meta-analysis-es/maive/actions

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Purpose: Continuous integration testing across platforms Triggers: Every push main Every pull request : Windows (R-release) macOS (R-release) Linux (R-release, R-devel, R-oldrel) Uploads check results Updates status badge monitor: Check README badge View Actions tab GitHub Receive email notifications failures

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Purpose: Track test coverage Triggers: Every push main Every pull request : Runs test suite coverage tracking Uploads results Codecov (configured) Updates coverage badge Optional setup: Add CODECOV_TOKEN GitHub secrets Badge show README

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Purpose: Pre-submission validation Triggers: Manual (workflow_dispatch) Requires typing ‚ÄúCONFIRM‚Äù : Runs comprehensive CRAN checks Submits R-hub Provides submission guidance automatically submit CRAN (manual step required) Safety features: Requires explicit confirmation Multiple check layers Human review final submission

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Issue: R CMD check returns notes Solutions: notes acceptable (e.g., ‚ÄúNew submission‚Äù) Read note carefully ‚ÄúNew submission‚Äù (first submission) ‚ÄúPossibly mis-spelled words‚Äù (‚Äôre correct technical terms) Unused dependencies Large package size without justification Unquoted URLs DESCRIPTION Check: Run devtools::check() see specific notes

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Issue: Examples documentation don‚Äôt run Solutions: Wrap long-running examples \donttest{} Wrap examples requiring user input \dontrun{} Ensure example data available Check missing library calls (use :: notation instead) Test examples: devtools::run_examples()

what: ‚ÄúTests fail in R CMD check but pass locally‚Äù
title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Issue: Tests work locally fail check Common causes solutions: Internet dependency: Mock external calls skip offline File writing: Use tempdir() instead user directories Random numbers: Set seed reproducibility Platform differences: Use skip_on_cran() platform-specific tests Parallel processing: May cause timing issues, consider sequential CRAN Check:
code: devtools::check(cran = TRUE)  # Mimics CRAN checks locally

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Issue: Package fails R-hub passes locally Solutions: R-hub stricter local checks Common issues: Missing system dependencies Path separators (use file.path()) Character encoding issues Platform-specific function calls Check R-hub output carefully specific errors Test specific platform:
code: rhub::rhub_check(platform = "windows-x86_64-devel")

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Issue: Package fails Windows works Unix Common issues: Path separators: Use file.path() paste ‚Äú/‚Äù Line endings: Git handle automatically Case sensitivity: Windows case-insensitive File locking: Windows locks files aggressively Solution:
code: devtools::check_win_devel()  # Test on Windows

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Issue: Documentation formatting incorrect Solutions: Use roxygen2, don‚Äôt edit .Rd files directly Check unescaped special characters: %, \, # Ensure cross-references exist Validate: devtools::check_man()

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Issue: Vignettes don‚Äôt build check Solutions: Ensure vignette dependencies Suggests Use eval=FALSE code needs special setup Don‚Äôt require internet connection Keep vignettes small fast Test: devtools::build_vignettes()

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Issue: GitHub Actions workflow doesn‚Äôt complete Common causes: Network timeouts: Add retries increase timeout Missing dependencies: Add DESCRIPTION workflow R version compatibility: Test matrix R versions Secrets missing: Check repository secrets settings Debug: View workflow logs Actions tab Check step--step output Reproduce locally possible

title: CRAN Submission Guide
text: Issue: README badge shows red Solutions: Click badge see workflow run Check platform failed Review error messages Fix issue push

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: guide explains complete development release workflow MAIVE package, including use Make commands vs.¬†direct script calls.

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: make test              # Run tests make check             # Run R CMD check make document          # Update documentation make version-patch     # Auto-bump version make release-prep      # Full release preparation

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: Rscript scripts/update-version.R    # Interactive version selection Rscript scripts/submit-cran.R       # Interactive CRAN submission Rscript scripts/check-cran.R        # Interactive check process Rscript scripts/build-docs.R        # Interactive doc build

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Make designed automation non-interactive workflows. : Chains commands together efficiently Works great CI/CD pipelines Can‚Äôt properly handle interactive prompts (stdin/stdout issues) Direct R scripts better interactive workflows : Properly handle user input via readline() Provide guided, step--step processes Give immediate feedback allow course correction

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: # 1. Make changes to R code vim R/maivefunction.r  # 2. Update documentation make document  # 3. Run tests make test  # 4. Quick check make quick-check  # 5. Commit when passing git commit -am "Add feature X"

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: # Edit documentation vim R/maivefunction.r  # Edit roxygen comments  # Update everything make update-docs  # Or build interactively with preview Rscript scripts/build-docs.R

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: # 1. Fix the bug vim R/maivefunction.r  # 2. Update version automatically make version-patch     # 0.0.4 -> 0.0.5  # 3. Update NEWS.md vim NEWS.md # Add: # MAIVE 0.0.5 #      * Fixed bug in X  # 4. Commit git add . git commit -m "Fix bug in X, bump to 0.0.5" git tag v0.0.5  # 5. Run checks make release-prep  # 6. Submit to CRAN Rscript scripts/submit-cran.R

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: # 1. Develop feature vim R/new-feature.r  # 2. Interactive version update (for NEWS.md prompt) Rscript scripts/update-version.R # Choose option 2 (minor) # Enter changes interactively  # Or quick automated bump make version-minor     # 0.0.4 -> 0.1.0  # 3. Full preparation make release-prep  # 4. Interactive submission Rscript scripts/submit-cran.R

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: # 1. Ensure breaking changes are documented vim NEWS.md  # 2. Update version make version-major     # 0.0.4 -> 1.0.0  # Or use interactive Rscript scripts/update-version.R  # 3. Comprehensive testing make release-prep  # 4. Submit Rscript scripts/submit-cran.R

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Best quick, non-interactive bumps: commands: ‚úÖ Update DESCRIPTION automatically ‚úÖ Print clear next steps ‚úÖ Fast scriptable ‚ùå Don‚Äôt prompt NEWS.md ‚ùå Don‚Äôt provide interactive guidance
code: # Current: 0.0.4  make version-patch    # -> 0.0.5 (bug fixes) make version-minor    # -> 0.1.0 (new features) make version-major    # -> 1.0.0 (breaking changes)

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Best guided, thoughtful releases: script: ‚úÖ Shows current version ‚úÖ Offers clear choices ‚úÖ Prompts NEWS.md updates ‚úÖ Provides step--step guidance ‚úÖ Handles custom versions ‚ùå Slightly slower ‚ùå suitable CI/CD Recommendation: Use interactive important releases, automated quick fixes.
code: Rscript scripts/update-version.R

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: # 1. Ensure version is updated make check-version    # Shows current version  # 2. Run comprehensive checks make release-prep     # This runs:                       # - clean                       # - document                       # - test                       # - cran-check  # 3. Review output # All checks should pass with 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Always use interactive script: walks : Pre-submission checklist Windows builder checks Actual CRAN submission Post-submission instructions automate CRAN submission - requires human review email confirmation.
code: Rscript scripts/submit-cran.R

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Use active development fast feedback.
code: make quick-check      # Fast check (skip vignettes)

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Use commits ensure nothing broken.
code: make check            # Full R CMD check

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Use CRAN submission. interactive version provides detailed feedback.
code: make cran-check       # Comprehensive check # Or interactive: Rscript scripts/check-cran.R

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Use creating releases.
code: make release-prep     # Everything

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: make document         # Update roxygen docs only

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: make update-docs      # Update docs + rebuild site

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: offers preview site browser.
code: Rscript scripts/build-docs.R

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: # Create branch git checkout -b feature/new-analysis  # Develop vim R/new-feature.r make document test  # Check before merge make check  # Merge git checkout main git merge feature/new-analysis

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: # Create release branch git checkout -b release/v0.1.0  # Prepare release make version-minor vim NEWS.md make release-prep  # Merge and tag git checkout main git merge release/v0.1.0 git tag v0.1.0 git push --tags

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Makefile commands work perfectly CI/CD:

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: - name: Check package   run: make check  - name: Build documentation   run: make site

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: #!/bin/bash # .git/hooks/pre-commit make quick-check || exit 1

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Problem: Running make update-version doesn‚Äôt show prompts. Solution: Use direct script call instead:
code: Rscript scripts/update-version.R

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Problem: Script waiting input Make doesn‚Äôt show . Solution: Interactive scripts always called directly, Make.

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Problem: Can‚Äôt use interactive scripts automated pipelines. Solution: Use Make commands automation:
code: make version-patch    # Automated version bump make release-prep     # Automated checks

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Use Make automated, repeatable tasks Use direct scripts interactive workflows Run make release-prep every release Call Rscript scripts/submit-cran.R submissions Keep version numbers semantic (X.Y.Z) Update NEWS.md every version bump Tag releases git

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Don‚Äôt call interactive scripts Make Don‚Äôt automate CRAN submission without review Don‚Äôt skip make release-prep Don‚Äôt forget update NEWS.md Don‚Äôt submit CRAN without running checks Don‚Äôt use emojis Unicode output (portability)

title: Development Workflow Guide
code: # Daily development make test make check make document  # Version management make check-version make version-patch Rscript scripts/update-version.R    # Interactive  # Release preparation make release-prep  # CRAN submission Rscript scripts/submit-cran.R       # Interactive  # Documentation make site make preview-site  # Cleanup make clean

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Run make help see available commands.

title: Development Workflow Guide
text: Makefile Help: make help Makefile Documentation: .github/MAKEFILE-USAGE.md CRAN Submission: .github/CRAN-SUBMISSION.md Package Issues: GitHub Issues workflow guide maintained part MAIVE package repository. Updates improvements welcome.

title: Makefile Usage Guide
text: document describes use Makefile efficient MAIVE package development.

title: Makefile Usage Guide
text: Simply run make make help see available commands:
code: make help

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # After modifying R code make document test    # Update docs and run tests  # Before committing make check           # Run R CMD check

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # Update roxygen2 docs make document  # Build pkgdown site make site  # Preview site in browser make preview-site  # Update everything make update-docs

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # Run all tests make test  # Quick check (faster, skips vignettes) make quick-check  # Full CRAN check make cran-check  # Coverage report make coverage

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # Full pre-release preparation make release-prep  # Check current version make check-version  # Interactive submission make submit-cran

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # Check code style make lint  # Auto-format code make style  # Fix style and update docs make fix-style

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # Install dependencies make install-deps  # Install package locally make install

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # Remove built files make clean  # Deep clean (including docs/) make clean-all

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # 1. Start fresh make clean make install-deps  # 2. Develop feature # ... edit R files ...  # 3. Update docs and test make document test  # 4. Check everything works make check  # 5. Commit when passing git add . git commit -m "Add new feature"

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # 1. Update version number # Edit DESCRIPTION and NEWS.md  # 2. Full preparation make release-prep  # 3. Review checks # All tests should pass  # 4. Submit to CRAN make submit-cran  # 5. After acceptance, tag release git tag v0.0.5 git push --tags

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # 1. Edit roxygen comments or vignettes # ... edit files ...  # 2. Rebuild everything make update-docs  # 3. Preview changes make preview-site  # 4. When satisfied, commit git add . git commit -m "Update documentation"

title: Makefile Usage Guide
text: Makefile located project root can customized specific needs. Common customizations:

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # Add to Makefile my-custom-task:  @echo "Running my custom task..."  @Rscript -e "my_function()"

title: Makefile Usage Guide
code: # Create workflows by chaining existing targets my-workflow: document test check  @echo "Workflow complete!"

title: Makefile Usage Guide
text: Enable tab completion make targets:
code: # Add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc complete -W "$(make -qp | awk -F':' '/^[a-zA-Z0-9][^$#\/\t=]*:([^=]|$)/ {split($1,A,/ /);for(i in A)print A[i]}' | sort -u)" make

title: Makefile Usage Guide
text: targets can run parallel:
code: make -j4 document test  # Run 4 jobs in parallel

title: Makefile Usage Guide
text: See full R output:
code: make check VERBOSE=1

title: Makefile Usage Guide
text: See executed without running:
code: make -n check

title: Makefile Usage Guide
text: Ensure ‚Äôre package root directory Check Makefile exists properly formatted Make sure ‚Äôre using tab characters (spaces) indentation

text: Make sure Makefile readable:

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: MAIVE (Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator) addresses fundamental problem meta-analysis observational research: spurious precision. Traditional meta-analysis assigns weight studies lower standard errors, assuming higher precision. However, observational research, precision must estimated vulnerable manipulation practices like p-hacking achieve statistical significance. manipulation can invalidate: Inverse-variance weighting schemes Bias-correction methods like funnel plots Traditional publication bias corrections MAIVE introduces instrumental variable approach limit bias caused spurious precision meta-analysis.

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: observational research, researchers can inadvertently deliberately manipulate analyses achieve statistically significant results. includes: Selective reporting specifications Outcome switching Sample trimming Selective controls inclusion practices create spuriously precise estimates appear reliable actually . Traditional meta-analysis methods weight inverse variance overweight manipulated studies, leading biased conclusions.

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: MAIVE uses instrumental variables correct spurious precision: First-stage regression: Instruments potentially manipulated standard errors using inverse sample sizes (researchers easily manipulate) Second-stage regression: Uses instrumented standard errors meta-regression models approach provides: Robust meta-estimates account spurious precision Hausman-type tests comparing IV OLS estimates Anderson-Rubin confidence intervals weak instruments Publication bias tests based instrumented standard errors

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
code: # Install from CRAN (once published) install.packages("MAIVE")  # Or install development version from GitHub install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("meta-analysis-es/maive") library(MAIVE)

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: maive() function expects data frame following columns:

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Let‚Äôs create simple example dataset:
code: # Simulated meta-analysis data set.seed(123) n_studies <- 50  data <- data.frame(   bs = rnorm(n_studies, mean = 0.3, sd = 0.2),   sebs = runif(n_studies, min = 0.05, max = 0.3),   Ns = sample(100:1000, n_studies, replace = TRUE),   study_id = rep(1:10, each = 5) )  head(data) #>          bs      sebs  Ns study_id #> 1 0.1879049 0.1999972 342        1 #> 2 0.2539645 0.1332059 961        1 #> 3 0.6117417 0.1721533 946        1 #> 4 0.3141017 0.2886185 891        1 #> 5 0.3258575 0.1707256 212        1 #> 6 0.6430130 0.2725876 718        2

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: default MAIVE estimator uses PET-PEESE instrumented standard errors, weights, cluster-robust standard errors, wild bootstrap:
code:
# Run MAIVE with defaults result <- maive(   dat = data,   method = 3,      # PET-PEESE (default)   weight = 0,      # No weights (default)   instrument = 1,  # Instrument SEs (default)   studylevel = 2,  # Cluster-robust (default)   SE = 3,          # Wild bootstrap (default)   AR = 1           # Anderson-Rubin CI (default) )  # View key results cat("MAIVE Estimate:", round(result$Estimate, 3), "
") cat("MAIVE SE:", round(result$SE, 3), "
") cat("Standard Estimate:", round(result$StdEstimate, 3), "
") cat("Hausman Test:", round(result$Hausman, 3), "
") cat("First-stage F-test:", round(result$`F-test`, 3), "
")

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: maive() function returns list following key elements: Estimate: MAIVE point estimate (corrected spurious precision) SE: MAIVE standard error StdEstimate: Standard (non-IV) estimate comparison Hausman: Hausman-type test comparing IV vs OLS estimates (high value suggests spurious precision) F-test: First-stage F-test instrument strength AR_CI: Anderson-Rubin confidence interval (robust weak instruments) pbias_pval: p-value publication bias test SE_instrumented: Vector instrumented standard errors

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: MAIVE supports multiple meta-regression methods:

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
code: result_pet <- maive(   dat = data,   method = 1,  # FAT-PET   weight = 0,   instrument = 1,   studylevel = 2,   SE = 3,   AR = 1 )  cat("PET Estimate:", round(result_pet$Estimate, 3), "\n")

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
code: result_peese <- maive(   dat = data,   method = 2,  # PEESE   weight = 0,   instrument = 1,   studylevel = 2,   SE = 3,   AR = 1 )  cat("PEESE Estimate:", round(result_peese$Estimate, 3), "\n")

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: PET-PEESE uses PET PET estimate significantly different zero, otherwise uses PEESE:
code: result_petpeese <- maive(   dat = data,   method = 3,  # PET-PEESE (default)   weight = 0,   instrument = 1,   studylevel = 2,   SE = 3,   AR = 1 )  cat("PET-PEESE Estimate:", round(result_petpeese$Estimate, 3), "\n")

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
code: result_ek <- maive(   dat = data,   method = 4,  # EK   weight = 0,   instrument = 1,   studylevel = 2,   SE = 3,   AR = 0  # AR not available for EK )  cat("EK Estimate:", round(result_ek$Estimate, 3), "\n")

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Unweighted regression, recommended spurious precision concern:
code: result_noweight <- maive(   dat = data,   method = 3,   weight = 0,  # No weights   instrument = 1,   studylevel = 2,   SE = 3,   AR = 1 )

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Traditional meta-analysis weighting:
code: result_ivweight <- maive(   dat = data,   method = 3,   weight = 1,  # Inverse-variance weights   instrument = 1,   studylevel = 2,   SE = 3,   AR = 0  # AR not available with weights )

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Uses instrumented standard errors weighting:
code: result_maiveweight <- maive(   dat = data,   method = 3,   weight = 2,  # MAIVE-adjusted weights   instrument = 1,   studylevel = 2,   SE = 3,   AR = 1 )

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Control study-level correlation multiple estimates per study:
code: # No study-level adjustment result_none <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                       studylevel = 0, SE = 0, AR = 1)  # Study fixed effects (demeaned) result_fe <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                    studylevel = 1, SE = 1, AR = 0)  # AR not available with FE  # Cluster-robust standard errors result_cluster <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                         studylevel = 2, SE = 3, AR = 1)  # Both fixed effects and clustering result_both <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                      studylevel = 3, SE = 3, AR = 0)

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
code: # CR0 (Huber-White) result_cr0 <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                     studylevel = 2, SE = 0, AR = 1)  # CR1 (Standard empirical correction) result_cr1 <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                     studylevel = 2, SE = 1, AR = 1)  # CR2 (Bias-reduced estimator) result_cr2 <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                     studylevel = 2, SE = 2, AR = 1)  # Wild bootstrap (recommended, default) result_boot <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                      studylevel = 2, SE = 3, AR = 1)

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: MAIVE allows two functional forms first-stage regression:

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Regresses variance (sebs¬≤) constant 1/Ns:
code: result_levels <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                        studylevel = 2, SE = 3, AR = 1, first_stage = 0)  cat("First-stage (levels) F-test:", round(result_levels$`F-test`, 3), "\n")

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Log-linear regression smearing retransformation:
code: result_log <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                     studylevel = 2, SE = 3, AR = 1, first_stage = 1)  cat("First-stage (log) F-test:", round(result_log$`F-test`, 3), "\n")

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: WAIVE (Weighted Instrumented Variable Estimator) provides additional robustness downweighting studies spurious precision extreme outliers: WAIVE particularly useful : suspect extreme outliers data Standard errors may severely manipulated want automatic downweighting problematic studies
code: result_waive <- waive(   dat = data,   method = 3,   instrument = 1,   studylevel = 2,   SE = 3,   AR = 1 )  cat("WAIVE Estimate:", round(result_waive$Estimate, 3), "\n") cat("WAIVE SE:", round(result_waive$SE, 3), "\n")

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Hausman test compares MAIVE (IV) estimate standard (OLS) estimate: High value: Suggests spurious precision problem; MAIVE estimate preferred Low value: IV OLS similar; spurious precision may severe

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Tests strength instrument (inverse sample size): F > 10: Strong instrument F < 10: Weak instrument; use Anderson-Rubin CI

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Provides inference robust weak instruments. Always check CI F-test low.

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Tests publication bias using instrumented FAT: Low p-value: Evidence publication bias High p-value: Little evidence publication bias

title: Getting Started with MAIVE
text: Irsova, Z., Bom, P. R. D., Havranek, T., & Rachinger, H. (2024). Spurious Precision Meta-Analysis Observational Research. Available : http://meta-analysis.cz/maive/ Keane, M., & Neal, T. (2023). Instrument strength IV estimation inference: guide theory practice. Journal Econometrics, 235(2), 1625-1653.

text: ?maive detailed parameter documentation ?waive robust WAIVE estimator Project website: http://meta-analysis.cz/maive/

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
text: MAIVE addresses fundamental problem meta-analysis observational research: spurious precision. Traditional meta-analysis assigns weight studies lower standard errors, assuming higher precision. However, observational research, precision can manipulated p-hacking questionable research practices, invalidating: Inverse-variance weighting schemes Traditional bias-correction methods (funnel plots, trim--fill) Selection models publication bias MAIVE implements instrumental variable approach limit bias caused spurious precision meta-analysis.

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
code: install.packages("MAIVE")

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
code: install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("meta-analysis-es/maive")

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
code: library(MAIVE)

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
code: # Prepare your data data <- data.frame(   bs = c(...),        # Effect sizes   sebs = c(...),      # Standard errors   Ns = c(...),        # Sample sizes   study_id = c(...)   # Study IDs (optional) )  # Run MAIVE with defaults (PET-PEESE, instrumented SEs, no weights) result <- maive(   dat = data,   method = 3,      # PET-PEESE (default)   weight = 0,      # No weights (default)   instrument = 1,  # Instrument SEs (default)   studylevel = 2,  # Cluster-robust (default)   SE = 3,          # Wild bootstrap (default)   AR = 1           # Anderson-Rubin CI (default) )  # View results print(result$Estimate)    # MAIVE estimate print(result$SE)          # Standard error print(result$Hausman)     # Hausman test print(result$`F-test`)    # First-stage F-test

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
text: maive() function expects data frame :

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
text: PET (Precision-Effect Test) PEESE (Precision-Effect Estimate Standard Error) PET-PEESE (Conditional method, default) EK (Endogenous Kink)

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
text: weights (recommended spurious precision concern) Inverse-variance weights MAIVE-adjusted weights (using instrumented SEs) WAIVE weights (robust downweighting via waive() function)

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
text: Study-level correlation (fixed effects, clustering, ) Multiple SE estimators (CR0, CR1, CR2, wild bootstrap) Anderson-Rubin confidence intervals weak instruments First-stage specification options (levels log transformation)

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
text: function returns: MAIVE point estimate standard error Standard (non-IV) estimate comparison Hausman-type test statistic First-stage F-test instrument strength Anderson-Rubin confidence interval Publication bias test p-value Instrumented standard errors

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
text: Getting Started Guide: See vignette("introduction") Function Reference: ?maive ?waive Development Workflow: .github/DEVELOPMENT-WORKFLOW.md CRAN Submission: .github/CRAN-SUBMISSION.md Project Page: http://meta-analysis.cz/maive/

title: MAIVE - Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator
code:
# Create example data set.seed(123) data <- data.frame(   bs = rnorm(50, mean = 0.3, sd = 0.2),   sebs = runif(50, min = 0.05, max = 0.3),   Ns = sample(100:1000, 50, replace = TRUE),   study_id = rep(1:10, each = 5) )  # Run MAIVE result <- maive(data, method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,                  studylevel = 2, SE = 3, AR = 1)  # Compare with standard estimate cat("MAIVE Estimate:", result$Estimate, "
") cat("Standard Estimate:", result$StdEstimate, "
") cat("Hausman Test:", result$Hausman, "
")  # Use WAIVE for robust estimation with outlier downweighting result_waive <- waive(data, method = 3, instrument = 1,                        studylevel = 2, SE = 3, AR = 1) cat("WAIVE Estimate:", result_waive$Estimate, "
")

what: MAIVE: Meta Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî MAIVE-package
title: MAIVE: Meta Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî MAIVE-package
text: Meta-analysis traditionally assigns weight studies lower standard errors, assuming higher precision. However, observational research, precision must estimated vulnerable manipulation, p-hacking, achieve statistical significance. can lead spurious precision, invalidating inverse-variance weighting bias-correction methods like funnel plots. Common methods addressing publication bias, including selection models, often fail exacerbate problem. package introduces instrumental variable approach limit bias caused spurious precision meta-analysis. Methods described Irsova et al. (2025) doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63261-0 .

title: MAIVE: Meta Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî MAIVE-package
text: Maintainer: Petr Cala cala.p@seznam.cz (Charles University, Prague) Authors: Zuzana Irsova (Charles University, Prague) Pedro R. D. Bom (University Deusto, Bilbao) Tomas Havranek (Charles University, Prague; CEPR, London; METRICS, Stanford) Heiko Rachinger (University Balearic Islands, Palma)

title: Joint Anderson-Rubin CI computation ‚Äî compute_AR_CI_optimized
text: Computes AR confidence intervals using 2D grid search (b0, b1) chi^2_2 critical value. slope (Egger) coefficient weak instruments, use method = "slope_only" instead.

title: Joint Anderson-Rubin CI computation ‚Äî compute_AR_CI_optimized
code: compute_AR_CI_optimized(   model,   adjust_fun,   bs,   sebs,   invNs,   g,   type_choice,   weights = NULL,   method = "joint" )

title: Joint Anderson-Rubin CI computation ‚Äî compute_AR_CI_optimized
text: model Fitted lm object second-stage regression adjust_fun PET_adjust PEESE_adjust function bs Effect estimates sebs Standard errors invNs Inverse sample sizes (instrument) g Cluster variable type_choice CR variance type ("CR0", "CR1", "CR2") weights Optional weights weighted AR method "joint" 2D grid, "slope_only" subset AR (robust weak IV)

what: Subset Anderson-Rubin CI for the slope coefficient ‚Äî compute_AR_CI_slope_only
title: Subset Anderson-Rubin CI for the slope coefficient ‚Äî compute_AR_CI_slope_only
text: Computes weak-instrument-robust AR confidence interval slope (Egger) coefficient treating intercept nuisance parameter.

title: Subset Anderson-Rubin CI for the slope coefficient ‚Äî compute_AR_CI_slope_only
code: compute_AR_CI_slope_only(   model,   adjust_fun,   bs,   sebs,   invNs,   g,   type_choice,   weights = NULL )

title: Subset Anderson-Rubin CI for the slope coefficient ‚Äî compute_AR_CI_slope_only
text: method robust weak instruments avoids "banana projection" artifact can produce spuriously narrow CIs projecting 2D joint AR regions. Algorithm (per tjhavranek, Nov 2025): 1. candidate slope b1, form residuals: r_i = y_i - b1 * x_i 2. Run auxiliary regression: r ~ 1 + z (intercept absorbs b0) 3. Use cluster-robust (CR2) variance z coefficient 4. Test statistic: t_z^2 clustered test 5. Accept b1 t_z^2 <= qchisq(0.95, df = 1) = 3.84 References: - Guggenberger, P., Kleibergen, F. (2012). Econometrica. - Andrews, D. W. K., & Mikusheva, . (2016). Econometrica.

title: R code for MAIVE ‚Äî maive
text: R package MAIVE: "Spurious Precision Meta-Analysis Observational Research" Zuzana Irsova, Pedro Bom, Tomas Havranek, Petr Cala, Heiko Rachinger.

title: R code for MAIVE ‚Äî maive
code: maive(dat, method, weight, instrument, studylevel, SE, AR, first_stage = 0L)

title: R code for MAIVE ‚Äî maive
text: dat Data frame columns bs, sebs, Ns, study_id (optional). method 1 FAT-PET, 2 PEESE, 3 PET-PEESE, 4 EK. weight 0 weights, 1 standard weights, 2 MAIVE adjusted weights, 3 study weights. instrument 1 yes, 0 . studylevel Correlation study level: 0 none, 1 fixed effects, 2 cluster. SE SE estimator: 0 CR0 (Huber-White), 1 CR1 (Standard empirical correction), 2 CR2 (Bias-reduced estimator), 3 wild bootstrap. AR Anderson Rubin corrected CI weak instruments (available unweighted MAIVE-adjusted weight versions PET, PEESE, PET-PEESE, available fixed effects): 0 , 1 yes. first_stage First-stage specification variance model: 0 levels, 1 log.

title: R code for MAIVE ‚Äî maive
text: beta: MAIVE meta-estimate SE: MAIVE standard error F-test: heteroskedastic robust F-test first step instrumented SEs beta_standard: point estimate method chosen SE_standard: standard error method chosen Hausman: Hausman type test: comparison MAIVE standard version Chi2: 5 SE_instrumented: instrumented standard errors AR_CI: Anderson-Rubin confidence interval weak instruments pub bias p-value: p-value test publication bias / p-hacking based instrumented FAT egger_coef: Egger Coefficient (PET estimate) egger_se: Egger Standard Error (PET standard error) egger_boot_ci: Confidence interval Egger coefficient using selected resampling scheme egger_ar_ci: Anderson-Rubin confidence interval Egger coefficient (available) is_quadratic_fit: Details quadratic selection slope behaviour boot_result: Boot result slope_coef: Slope coefficient petpeese_selected: model (PET PEESE) selected method=3 (NA otherwise) peese_se2_coef: Coefficient SE^2 PEESE final model (NA otherwise) peese_se2_se: Standard error PEESE SE^2 coefficient (NA otherwise)

title: R code for MAIVE ‚Äî maive
text: Data dat can imported Excel file via: dat <- read_excel("inputdata.xlsx") csv file via: dat <- read.csv("inputdata.csv") contain: Estimates: bs Standard errors: sebs Number observations: Ns Optional: study_id Default option MAIVE: MAIVE-PET-PEESE, unweighted, instrumented, cluster SE, wild bootstrap, AR.

title: R code for MAIVE ‚Äî maive
code: dat <- data.frame(   bs = c(0.5, 0.45, 0.55, 0.6),   sebs = c(0.25, 0.2, 0.22, 0.27),   Ns = c(50, 80, 65, 90) )  result <- maive(dat,   method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,   studylevel = 0, SE = 0, AR = 0, first_stage = 0 ) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'clubSandwich': #>   method    from     #>   bread.mlm sandwich

what: WAIVE: Weighted Adjusted Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî waive
title: WAIVE: Weighted Adjusted Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî waive
text: WAIVE extends MAIVE applying exponential-decay weights downweight studies spurious precision extreme outlier behavior.

title: WAIVE: Weighted Adjusted Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî waive
code: waive(dat, method, weight, instrument, studylevel, SE, AR, first_stage = 0L)

title: WAIVE: Weighted Adjusted Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî waive
text: dat Data frame columns bs, sebs, Ns, study_id (optional). method 1 FAT-PET, 2 PEESE, 3 PET-PEESE, 4 EK. weight 0 weights, 1 standard weights, 2 MAIVE adjusted weights, 3 study weights. instrument 1 yes, 0 . studylevel Correlation study level: 0 none, 1 fixed effects, 2 cluster. SE SE estimator: 0 CR0 (Huber-White), 1 CR1 (Standard empirical correction), 2 CR2 (Bias-reduced estimator), 3 wild bootstrap. AR Anderson Rubin corrected CI weak instruments (available unweighted MAIVE-adjusted weight versions PET, PEESE, PET-PEESE, available fixed effects): 0 , 1 yes. first_stage First-stage specification variance model: 0 levels, 1 log.

title: WAIVE: Weighted Adjusted Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî waive
text: List structure maive(). See ?maive details.

title: WAIVE: Weighted Adjusted Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî waive
text: Computes robust downweighting based first-stage residuals. Studies negative residuals (spurious precision) extreme residuals (outliers) receive reduced influence meta-analytic estimate.

title: WAIVE: Weighted Adjusted Instrumental Variable Estimator ‚Äî waive
code: dat <- data.frame(   bs = c(0.5, 0.45, 0.55, 0.6),   sebs = c(0.25, 0.2, 0.22, 0.27),   Ns = c(50, 80, 65, 90) )  result <- waive(dat,   method = 3, weight = 0, instrument = 1,   studylevel = 0, SE = 0, AR = 0, first_stage = 0 )

title: MAIVE 0.0.4
text: Implemented MAIVE (Meta-Analysis Instrumental Variable Estimator) addressing spurious precision meta-analysis maive(): Main function implementing PET, PEESE, PET-PEESE, Endogenous Kink (EK) methods waive(): Robust extension downweighting spurious precision outliers Instrumental variable approach using inverse sample sizes Multiple weighting schemes (weights, inverse-variance, MAIVE-adjusted, WAIVE) Study-level correlation handling (fixed effects, clustering, ) Robust standard errors (CR0, CR1, CR2, wild bootstrap) Anderson-Rubin confidence intervals weak instruments First-stage specification options (levels log transformation) Publication bias testing based instrumented FAT Comprehensive test suite 9 test files Documentation examples usage guidelines
